column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0368] It is thought that, although absolute surface area is increased on substrates growing nanofibers, the low solid surface volume, lack of continuity and nanoscale aspect of the fibers discourages cellular attachment.

#Text=The nanowire surfaces used in these illustrations herein was produced for an electronics application and was not optimized for this use, yet, as will be noted, such surfaces still reduced biofilm accumulation.
#Text=The silicon wires utilized were .about.40 nm in diameter and 50 to 100 um in length and were grown on a four inch silicon substrate.
#Text=The nanowire preparation method is described below.
#Text=In the current example, the nanowire pieces used in this experiment were about 0.25 cm.sup.2.
#Text=Immediately before introduction into the culture media they were soaked in 100% ethanol and blown dry with a stream of nitrogen.
#Text=Silicon wafer controls (i.e., without nanowires) were also soaked in ethanol and blown dry.
#Text=S. epidermidis was grown in LB broth for 6 hours at 37.degree.
#Text=C. with gentle shaking in 35 mm Petri dishes.
#Text=Wafer sections were then placed in the culture and left for 24 hours at 37.degree.
#Text=C. in the original media.

#Text=The wafer slices were removed after 24 hours incubation, washed briefly in fresh media, rapidly immersed in water and then heat fixed for 30 seconds prior to staining in a 0.2% crystal violet solution.
#Text=The wafer segments were rinsed thoroughly in water.
#Text=Any microbes attached to the wafers were visualized by conventional brightfield microscopy.
#Text=Images were captured with a digital camera.
#Text=The results showed approximately a ten fold decrease in bacteria on the nanowire substrate as compared to the silicon wafer control.
#Text=Quantitation was performed on the microscope by focusing through the nanowires since the thickness of the nanowire layer was greater than the depth of field of the microscope.

#Text=[0369] To illustrate the nanofiber surfaces' repulsion of mammalian cells, CHO cells were maintained in culture in complete media (Hams F12 media supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum) at 37.degree.
#Text=C. in a 5% CO.sub.2 atmosphere.
#Text=Wafer segments were placed in 35 mm cell culture treated Petri dishes.
#Text=CHO cells were seeded into the dishes at a density of 10.sup.6 cell/ml in complete media after trypsinization from confluent culture.
#Text=The cells were allowed to adhere overnight and were then observed microscopically every 24 hours.
#Text=The surface of the 35 mm Petri dish was confluent at 48 hours when the first observation was made.
#Text=No cell growth was observed directly on the nanowire surface.
#Text=Where the nanowires had been removed by scratching the surface with a knife the cells adhered and grew.
#Text=Silicon wafer controls became confluent with cells.
#Text=In these experiments complete retardation of mammalian cellular growth and approximately a 10.times. reduction in bacterial growth was observed.

#Text=The control surfaces were chemically identical to the nanowires so it is thought that reduction in cell and bacterial growth is due to the unique surface morphology of the nanofiber enhanced surface area substrates.
#Text=[0370] S. epidermidis was used in the illustrations herein because it is a representative bacteria involved in infections of medical devices.
#Text=Additionally, S. epidermidis has been widely used in the evaluation of biomaterials and has been identified as a dominant species in biomaterial centered infections.

#Text=Other bacteria implicated in biomaterial related infections such as S. aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and B-hemolytic streptococci are also contemplated as being prohibited through use of current embodiments.

#Text=In addition to CHO cells illustrated herein, other common tissue culture lines such as, e.g., MDCK, L-929 and HL60 cells are also contemplated as being prohibited through use of current embodiments.
#Text=Such cell lines represent a wide diversity of cell types.
#Text=The CHO and MDCK cells are representative of epithelial cells, L-929 cells participate in the formation of connective tissue and the HL60 line represents immune surveillance cells.
#Text=Thus, the nanofiber enhanced surface areas herein are contemplated against these cell types and other common in vivo cell types.

#Text=The nanofibers used in the in vitro illustration herein were made of silicon, and, as detailed throughout, several methods have been reported in the literature for the synthesis of silicon nanowires.
#Text=For example, laser ablating metal-containing silicon targets, high temperature vaporizing of Si/SiO.sub.2 mixture, and vapor-liquid-solid (VLS) growth using gold as the catalyst.
#Text=See, above.
#Text=While any method of construction is optionally used, the approach to nanowire synthesis is typically VLS growth since this method has been widely used for semiconductor nanowire growth.
#Text=Description of such method is provided elsewhere herein.

#Text=[0371] As mentioned previously, it is thought that the primary means of biofilm prevention by nanofiber surfaces herein is due to the unique morphology of the substrate, however, it is also possible that such substrates comprise inherent cytophobicity activity.

#Text=[0372] The effect of surface hydrophilicity or hydrophobicity on growth is also optionally modified on the nanofiber substrates herein to specifically tailor biofilm prevention in different situations.
#Text=Such functionalization goes along with variability in wire length, diameter and density on the substrate.
#Text=The silicon oxide surface layer of the typical nanofiber substrates is quite hydrophilic in its native state.
#Text=Water readily wets the surface and spreads out evenly.
#Text=This is partially due to the wicking properties of the surface.
#Text=Functionalization of the surface is facilitated by the layer of native oxide that forms on the surface of the wires.
#Text=This layer of SiO.sub.2 can be modified using standard silane chemistry to present functional groups on the outside of the wire.
#Text=For example the surface can be treated with gaseous hexamethyldisilane (HMDS) to make it extremely hydrophobic.
#Text=See, above.
#Text=In addition, it is possible to use multi-component nanofiber surfaces to tailor a medical device for a particular application.

#Text=For example, a hydrophobic (or hydrophilic) nanofiber surface which resists cellular attachment (and thus biofilm formation) as described above can also be specifically tailored to allow one or more specific types of cells such as endothelial cells, osteoblasts, etc. to grow on some (or all) portions of the surface (e.g., where cellular integration and proliferation is needed), e.g., by modifying the hydrophobic (or hydrophilic) nanofiber surface with functional groups (e.g., fibronectin, collagen, RGD containing peptides, extracellular matrix proteins, chemoattracts, and other cell binding motifs)--which promote cellular attachment and integration.
#Text=The hydrophobic layer may diminish over time as the desired cells integrate.

#Text=Thus, medical devices such as catheters, implants and the like can be engineered to resist biofilm formation over portions of or their entire surface by rendering the nanofiber surface hydrophobic as described above and in co-pending U.S.
#Text=Ser.

#Text=No. 10/833,944, filed Apr. 27, 2004, the entire contents of which are incorporated by reference herein, and then the surface coverage of one or more functional groups on the hydrophobic surface can be precisely controlled to encourage cellular attachment in specific areas where tissue integration is most desirable (e.g., where grafting or bonding is to occur).
#Text=Examples of multicomponent films are demonstrated and described, for example, in T.
#Text=M.
#Text=Heme et al., Characterization of DNA Probes Immobilized on Gold Surfaces, J.
#Text=Am.
#Text=Chem.
#Text=Soc. 1997, 119, 8916-8920 (e.g., FIG. 4), the entire contents of which are incorporated by reference herein."
